data.title: Nobel laureate Oe a finalist for Man Asian prize
data.meta_description: Nobel Prize winner Kenzaburo Oe and debut novelist Manu Joseph are among five finalists for the Man Asian Literary Prize, an international award for Asian writers.
data.text:
Nobel Prize winner Kenzaburo Oe and debut novelist Manu Joseph are among five finalists for the Man Asian Literary Prize, an international award for Asian writers.

Oe, one of Japan's most respected post-war writers, has received both the 1994 Nobel Prize for Literature and the 1989 Priz Europalia.

Two writers from Japan, two from India and one from China are on the short list, announced Tuesday in Hong Kong.

"Our judges have chosen five very different novels, each in its own way brilliant and captivating," said David Parker, chair of the prize's board.

The finalists are:

Three Sisters by Bi Feiyu of China: A family story set during China's Cultural Revolution.

Serious Men by Manu Joseph of India: A comedy of manners about a man trying to escape the slums of Mumbai.

The Thing about Thugs by Tabish Khair of India: A story exploring the life of an Indian thug, set against the backdrop of Victorian England.

The Changeling by Kenzaburo Oe of Japan: A writer in his 60s explores his brother-in-law's past after the man commits suicide.

Hotel Iris by Yoko Ogawa of Japan: A novel exploring the dark side of intimacy.

Joseph's novel is also in the running for the Commonwealth Prize.

Organizers received 54 works from all over Asia for this year's prize. To be eligible, novels must be written in or translated into English.

The five finalists will give readings from their nominated books and participate in an audience question-and-answer session at the Hong Kong International Literary Festival March 16.

The winner of the $30,000 US prize will be named at a Hong Kong gala on March 17.
